note.p: This letter was written by Sir Hubert de la Poer Gough (1870 - 1963). Gough was a senior officer in the British Army in the First World War. In 1916 he was promoted to lead the Reserve Army, renamed the ‘Fifth Army’, from the Somme offensive to the retreat of March 1918.
The letter was addressed to Augustine Birrell (1850 - 1933). Birrell was the chief secretary for Ireland from 1907 until his retirement in 1916 following the aftermath of the Easter Rising.
This letter is an inquiry into what is happening in areas around Galway. As there are no ports, telegraphs or railways are open, Gough fears that 'regrettable events are occurring'.
A note on the letter indicates that the letter was received by the General Secretary's Office quite late (10 May), and is therefore not being answered as it is presumed the county is now quiet.

div.note:
A.U.S.
This has only reached us now as Lord Gough
has since written to the
C. Sec. I am not answering
This letter. I presume all is
quiet now. APM 10/1/16
div.p:
I should be obliged if you
would — provided there be no objection —
inquire into the proceedings since
Easter Monday, April 24, in the following
places near Lough Cutra viz: Athenry
Craughwell, Moyode Castle, and Kinvara.
No post or telegraph or railway is open
and there is good reason to think that
regrettable events are occurring.
div.note:
The Rt Honble Birrell M.P.
etc etc etc

As Under Secretary
at this date
no notice seems
to be called
for. WML11/5
